item.title: A resolution expressing support for the designation of the week of November 1 through November 5, 2021, as "National Family Service Learning Week".

latestAction.text: Submitted in the Senate, considered, and agreed to without amendment and with a preamble by Unanimous Consent. (consideration: CR S7760; text: CR S7724)

item.title: Expressing support for the designation of the week of November 14 through November 18, 2022, as "National Family Service Learning Week".

latestAction.text: Referred to the House Committee on Education and Labor.

item.title: A resolution expressing support for the designation of the week of November 14 through November 18, 2022, as "National Family Service Learning Week".

latestAction.text: Submitted in the Senate, considered, and agreed to without amendment and with a preamble by Unanimous Consent. (consideration: CR S7009; text: CR S7001)

item.text: Referred to the House Committee on Education and Labor.

item.name: Social work, volunteer service, charitable organizations

summary.text: This resolution (1) expresses support for the designation of National Family Service Learning Week, (2) recognizes the importance of family service learning in cultivating civic engagement and community investment, and (3) encourages the public to support family service learning and community development programs. Family service learning is a multigenerational problem-solving approach that utilizes active participation to meet community needs and develop the skill sets of children and families.

bill.title: Expressing support for the designation of the week of November 1 through November 5, 2021, as "National Family Service Learning Week".

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
